Recent advances in oxidation and degradation mechanisms of ultrathin 2D materials in ambient conditions and passivation strategies
Qiang Li,a Qionghua Zhou,a Li Shi,a Qian Chena and Jinlan Wanga,b*
The graphene like two-dimensional (2D) nanomaterials such as transition metal dichalcogenides and black phosphorus have been extensively studied in recent years due to the wealth of unusual physical and chemical properties that introduced when charge and heat transport is confined to a plane. However, many 2D materials with atomic scale thickness suffer oxidation and degradation in ambient conditions, which leads the biggest obstacle to practical applications. The research for related oxidation and degradation mechanisms is kept ongoing, and various protection strategies have been proposed and tested with promising progress. In this review, we focus on the insights of oxidation and degradation mechanisms of 2D materials, especially black phosphorus and transitional metal chalcogenides in ambient conditions from both theoretical results and experimental observations, also the state-of-the-art of protection strategies and corresponding passivation mechanisms are summarized.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The successful isolation of graphene from graphite in 2004 opened up new avenues by introducing two-dimensional (2D) systems from layered materials, which are dominated by surface effects and show completely unexpected and extraordinary properties.1, 2 The layered materials involve strong covalent bonding within each sheet and van der Waals interactions between adjacent sheets, which can be exfoliated down to few layers or even single layer limit. The ultrathin nanosheets, then, influence a 2D wave function of quantum confinement effects and entail them to modify the intrinsic physical properties by regulating the electronic band structure. The more recent emergence of 2D nanomaterials that beyond graphene, most prominently transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) and black phosphorus (BP), span the entire range of electronic structures, from insulator to metal, and exhibit electronic characteristics similar to, or even exceed graphene.3, 4
One of the well-studied families of van der Waals solids is TMDCs, which have a general chemical formula MX2, where M is a transition metal (e.g., Mo, Nb, and Hf) and X is a chalcogen, generally S, Se, or Te. They have diverse properties including a wide range of electronic band structures that depend on crystal symmetry and stoichiometric identity, such as semiconductivity, half-metallic magnetism, superconductivity, or
charge density wave (CDW).5, 6 Based on semiconductor property, TMDC field effect transistors (FETs) can achieve room temperature charge carrier mobilities in excess of ∼102 cm 2 V−1 s−1 with large on/off current ratios up to ∼108.7, 8 Being chemically and electronically active, 2D TMDCs nanostructures have shown great potential applications in optoelectronic/electronic devices, electrocatalysis, sensors and energy storage.9, 10 Chalcogen species can also combine with metals and forms MX or MX2, where M can be metals in Group III-IVA. Unlike indirect-to-direct bandgap transition generally occurring in semiconductor TMDCs, such as MoS2, MX like InSe exhibits a direct-to-indirect bandgap transition occurs during a decrease in sample thickness.11 Furthermore, carrier mobilities of MX can reach up 103 cm2 V−1 s−1 at room temperatures due to weak electron-phonon scattering and optical activity in absorption and emission.12
Like graphene, a strong interest in mono-elemental 2D buckled nanosheets has recently emerged, such as borophene, silicene and germanene, and they are found to exhibit electronic characteristics similar to graphene.4, 13 Black phosphorus (BP), which has been reintroduced as a member of 2D family in recent years, is emerging as a successor to other 2D nanomaterials due to its exceptional electronic properties.14-16 Unlike semimetallic graphene, BP is a semiconductor with a sizable band gap (∼0.3-2.0 eV), and on-off current ratios exceed 105.15-19 Remarkably, mechanically exfoliated 2D BP possesses mobility up to 1000 cm2V-1s-1 at room temperature.14, 15, 19 Therefore, the successful exfoliation of thin BP films bridge the gap between zero bandgap graphene and wide bandgap TMDCs, and the desirable electronic properties make 2D BP a a. Despite all these favorable properties, many ultrathin 2D materials bear very poor stability in ambient condition compared to their 3D counterparts, because they would corrode, decompose, segregate and so forth.24 Typical examples are the emerging BP and metallic TMDCs, which show observable morphology changes on the surfaces within few hours.25, 26 When exposed to an environment with moisture and oxygen, oxides are formed and oxidation of 2D materials adversely affects device performance and hinders research of its fundamental properties.26, 27 Here, we review the oxidation upon ambient exposure in 2D materials that beyond graphene, including BP, TMDCs and metal chalcogenides (Fig. 1). Specifically, we consider the roles of water, oxygen and light illumination from external environments, as well as the edges, grain boundaries and surface vacancies from internal defects. We summarize passivation strategies to prevent 2D materials from oxidation. The specific application of 2D semiconductors in field effect transistors is also addressed in this review. Finally, we close with a perspective of 2D material oxidation and protection research.

sections.heading: 2. Black Phosphorus
sections.text:
The novel properties of BP originate from its unique structural arrangement, as shown in Fig. 2a. The inner layer of BP has a puckered structure along the armchair direction, but it appears as a bilayer configuration along the zigzag direction. Such geometry configuration, on one hand, leads to substantial inplane anisotropic properties, including electrical transport thermoelectric, critical strain, Poisson’s ratio, Young’s modulus.15, 16, 28-31 On the other hand, the preparation of 2D BP by chemical vapor deposition (CVD), which has been widely used as a material processing technology and regarded as one of the most promising bottom-up methods, is restricted, since suitable substrate that matching the lattice can be hardly identified.32-34 Therefore, the fabrication of few-layer BP is mainly focused on top-down methods including exfoliation,
pulsed laser deposition, and plasma thinning.33-36 While micromechanical exfoliation generally produces 2D nanomaterials with the highest crystal quality, this method has limited scalability. Large quantities of 2D nanomaterials can also be produced by chemical exfoliation (e.g., lithium intercalation and oxidation), but this approach typically introduces defects and/or leads to phase transformations that compromise electronic properties.37 Recent advance proved that sonicationassisted liquid-phase exfoliation is an efficient and controllable way for yielding 2D BP at bulk scale.23-25 The selection of the optimum solvent plays a key role in utilizing the full potential of this technique, and various kinds of organic solvents, such as Nmethyl-2-pyrro-lidone (NMP), cumyl hydroperoxide, Ncyclohexyl-2-pyrrolidone (CHP), N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethyl sulfoxide, and acetone, have been used to prepare uniform and stable dispersions.38-44
The stability of layered BP promptly became a concern, and this specific issue is widely addressed and discussed in BPrelated reviews.33, 45-49 Nevertheless, there are few reviews paying attention to the in-depth mechanisms of oxidation, degradation, and corresponding passivation effect. In this section, we summarized our group’s very recent studies regarding BP degradation and other researches in the field. Specifically, we provide insights into the degradation process step by step through combining theoretical results and experimental observations. We list common approaches applied for passivation BP from ambient, and in particular, we illustrate the current understanding of the passivation mechanisms at atomic level.

sections.heading: 2.1 Oxidation and degradation mechanisms
sections.text:
Although BP exists as the most stable allotrope of phosphorus under normal conditions, the surface of BP bulks endures layer etching as observed by optical imagines and scanning tunneling microscopy.50, 51 The degradation phenomenon is more obvious when the thickness is reduced to a few layers, which present visible surface evolution within fewer hours.26 From the morphology of the BP surface by atomic force microscopy (AFM) or optical microscopy, small bumps (or termed as “bubbles”), which are inferred as phosphoric acid, appear (Fig. 2b).52 These nucleation spots grow rapidly with exposition time and finally coalesce after several days depending on the thickness of the material. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy characterization confirmed that POx peaks appeared after exposure of BP to air and the observed P−O stretching modes suggest that the formation of oxidized phosphorus leads to the property degradation (Fig. 2c).27, 53 Another common approach for identifying the oxidation of BP is Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2d), and typical features of pristine BP locates at A1g = 361 cm-1, B2g = 438 cm-1, and A2g = 466 cm-1.52 As the exposition time increases, the intensity of three BP features drops sharply, indicating fast oxidation of BP in ambient conditions. sections.heading: 2.1.1 Active species in air
sections.text:
The reactive species in the air that causing oxidation and degradation of BP, no doubt, are water and oxygen. In an early work by Gomez et al., they found BP flakes are very hydrophilic and that long-term exposure to air moisture etches BP away.26 Theoretical predictions indicate a large distortion of the lattice structure, which shrinks by around 25%, can be introduced by the dipole-dipole interactions between water and phosphorene. The band gap, in turn, changes also by 20%. A continuous work suggested that the strong affinity for water of
BP greatly modifies the performance of fabricated FETs measured in ambient conditions.54 Wang et al. concluded based on ab initio calculations that H2O does not interact directly (chemically) with the pristine phosphorene lattice.55 It prefers to bind to the surface of phosphorene through hydrogen bonds. Huang et al. confirmed the weak interaction between pristine BP and water by isotope labeling experiments, contact angle measurements, and density functional theory (DFT) calculations.56 The BP flakes with monolayer and bilayer areas exposed to deaerated H2O for 2 days remained almost completely unchanged (Fig. 3a&b). In a control experiment, few-layer flakes, which was immersed in water enriched in dissolved oxygen by O2 bubbling, were completely etched away, indicating that the pristine BP surface is hydrophobic but is turned progressively hydrophilic by oxidation. As shown in Fig. 3c&d, the valence band maximum (VBM) of BP is mainly distributed by Pz orbitals, thus the lone pair of BP surface atoms can be easily oxidized by oxygen. The oxidation process of BP surface involves a spin cross from triplet oxygen (degenerate π orbitals) to singlet, leading to an intermediate of a diagonal molecular bridge with an energy barrier of 0.54 eV (Fig. 3e).57 Subsequently, dangling oxygen bonds can be readily formed by overcoming a small energy barrier of 0.15 eV. The whole reaction is exothermic with 3.9 eV, but the energy barrier of 0.54 eV for O=O activation by BP surface still requires extra
energy from either thermally or possibly from light-induced excitation of the O 2p electrons. Based on this fact, it is not surprising that exfoliated BP can survive in a pure O2 environment or in dry air (in the absence of light) for a considerable long time without much loss of pristine properties.58-60 Therefore, the fast oxidation of BP is a consequence of combining factors including oxygen, water, temperature, and light, as seen in many experiments. 52, 58, 60

Under normal conditions, the incident light can serve as the excitation source to initiate the chemical reaction between BP and oxygen. Using in situ Raman and transmission electron spectroscopies, Favron et al. proposed that the light-induced excitons produce the charge carriers for transfer reaction towards oxygen molecules and generate reactive intermediate superoxide anions, O2-.52 The reactive species thus react spontaneously with p-doped 2D-phosphane to form oxides. The oxidation rate of BP increases linearly with oxygen concentration and light intensity. Ahmed et al. investigated the influence of discrete wavelengths ranging from ultraviolet to infrared on the degradation of BP by AFM and electrical characterizations, and the results showed that the ultraviolet component of the spectrum is primarily responsible for the deterioration of BP in ambient conditions.61 From a theoretical point of view, the electronic structure of the reactants plays an essential role in the light-induced reactions, such as water splitting and photo-catalysis reactions. To make a direct impression, our group lined the band alignment of BP with a redox potential of O2-O2-.62 The band structure at HSE level is shown in Fig. 4a, and the valence band maximum (VBM) and conduction band minimum (CBM) of the monolayer (ML) BP with respect to vacuum energy are -5.46 and -3.95 eV separately, which gives a direct band gap of 1.51 eV at G point. It is noteworthy that the redox potential of O2-O2- locates inside the band gap. Therefore, the photo-generated electrons from the conduction band of phosphorene can transfer to the O2 on the surface and generate superoxide anions, which further react with p-doped BP surfaces. Comparing with the reaction barrier of 0.54 eV between O2 with BP surface, the energy barrier for oxidation of BP by reactive O2- lowers to 0.4 eV. It should be noted that the bilayer BP is hole doped by the light excitation, which was not included in our calculations. In other words, on account of the strong Coulomb interaction between O2- and p-typed BP, the reaction barrier should be even lower in reality. The BP oxidation, similar to its electronic properties, is thickness dependent.52 The photo-oxidation takes longer for BP consisting of six or more layers than the thinner flakes (Fig. 4c). sections.heading: 2.1.3 Water catalyzed oxidation mechanism
sections.text:
In addition to light-induced oxidation mechanism, the concentration of water (humidity) is proven to have a significant effect on the oxidation of BP. Our recent work, by monitoring the electrical transport as well as spectroscopic properties of BP in well-controlled gas ambient, found that the humid oxygen initiates oxidization of BP even in dark environment (Fig. 4d).59 The oxidation was further revealed by in situ x-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements, and BP device performance showed over two orders of magnitudes decrease for both hole and electron motility after 19.5 h exposure. The water assisted oxidation of BP is attributed to the polarization effect of water molecules, which can largely increase the electron affinity of oxygen when water and oxygen molecules co-adsorbed on BP surface and forming wateroxygen superclusters. As shown in Fig. 4e, the energy levels of π*2p of O2 are lowered and get closer to the valence bands of BP upon the presence of H2O, and the electron accepting ability is significantly enhanced. Consequently, obvious charge transfer from BP surface to O2 through H2O is identified by periodic DFT calculation, and hence O2- anions are expected even without light induction.
Overall, the light oxidation mechanism and the water catalyzed oxidation mechanism indicate that the synergetic effects of light, water, and oxygen are a fundamental cause of the oxidation of phosphorene. Depending on the oxygen concentration, oxidation of phosphorene can lead to the formation of a new family of planar (two-dimensional) and tubular (one-dimensional) oxides and suboxides, most of which are insulating with large band gaps up to 8.5 eV. The electronic properties of BP can be largely affected by the formation of oxides.

sections.heading: 2.1.4 Degradation mechanism
sections.text:
The pristine BP is hydrophobic, as we discussed above. However, the surface will be polarized once some oxygen atoms are chemisorbed, due to the difference in electronegativity between O and P, and will become more hydrophilic. Huang et al. conducted wetting experiments involving BP surfaces that have been preoxidized by extended (∼10 h) exposure to air. On these surfaces, sessile drops can no longer be stabilized, and the water rapidly spreads upon contact, indicating strongly hydrophilic behavior after more extensive oxidation of the surface (Fig. 4f).56 Room temperature AIMD simulations show that one of the dangling O atoms and its bonded P atom are lifted off the surface by the dragging of H2O, which connects to the O via hydrogen-bond, after about 1.3 ps (Fig. 4g).62 The P-P bond connected to the lower P is broken, and this may cause further oxidation of exposed P atoms to higher oxidation states, e.g PO43-. In the meantime, the structure reconstruction would correspond to experimentally observed bubbles, the height of which increases vertically on the sample surface. The lone pair of surface P atoms is the origin of the reaction between BP and oxygen, but the direct oxidation requires energy barrier of 0.54 eV, suggesting BP can be stabilized in a pure oxygen environment with moderate temperature. sections.heading: 2.2 Protection strategies and passivation mechanisms
sections.text:
BP is the first investigated 2D material to undergo noticeable degradation upon exposure to ambient air. This stability problem has been critically addressed, and effective protection to prevent the degradation process is critical for BP in practical applications. Currently, most of the BP devices are fabricated in a vacuum or inert gas, but the devices are required to work in air and ambient atmosphere compatible for many commercial applications. Various strategies have been proposed and tested for effective passivation of BP, while the high requirements of ultrathin 2D materials based devices, including both long-term stability and high performance, is still highly challenging. sections.heading: 2.2.1.1 ALD and 2D heterostructures
sections.text: The most commonly used method is encapsulation (or coating) with environment stable materials, which isolate BP from direct contact with air. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) or chemical vapor deposition of AlOx, Al2O3, TiO2, SiO2, HfO2 etc. shows promise to protect BP flakes that can be stable for weeks or months in ambient environments, and this technique is one of the most promising in terms of industrial application and scalability (Fig. 5a).27, 37, 63-72 However, the ALD process involves inherent oxidation and degradation of BP due to the precursors of water, resulting in the increase of interface trap density.27, 65, 73 On the other hand, encapsulation of sandwiched BPhexagonal boron nitride (hBN), BP-MoS2 or BP-graphene, using a procedure based on the dry transfer method developed for the preparation of 2D stacked-layer heterostructures, produces a distinct layered structure by vertical assembling without restriction by the lattice compatibility and the vdW interfaces can protect BP simultaneously (Fig. 5b).74-80 Nevertheless, the preparation of a hybrid structure requires expensive equipment, sophisticated technologies, and longtime up to weeks, also the throughput is low.45, 81

sections.heading: 2.2.1.2 Surface oxidation
sections.text: Applying ab initio calculations of the electronic structure as well as molecular dynamics simulations, theoretical results suggest that the formation of P-O-P bonds can greatly stabilize the BP layers.62 The degradation of BP (section 2.3), i.e. the breaking of P-P bonds, can be avoided by replacement of P-O bonds as water approaching BP surface, thus as fully surface oxidation is expected to turn into a protective layer (Fig. 5c). Such an oxidization of the surface could effectively prevent few-layer BP from deterioration and leave the underlying BP layers intact with high hole mobility. The prediction is consistent with the experimental observation that phosphorus oxide only forms at the top layer of bulk BP and offers great potential as a stable and protective capping layer.53 Furthermore, the stable phosphorus oxide layer can be used for optoelectronic devices utilizing BP or few-layer phosphorene because of its transparency in the UV, and potentially be the thinnest hyperferroelectric material for certain phosphorus oxide single sheets (P2O3).53, 82 Pei et al. obtained BP devices with long lifetime and still show very clean surfaces even after 2 months in air by dual layers encapsulation of PxOy and Al2O3.37 The mono- and bi-layer phosphorene samples fabricated by O2 plasma etching can be coated with ALD Al2O3 without any damage to the underlying phosphorene because of presence of the PxOy capping layer.

sections.heading: 2.2.1.3 Organic coating
sections.text:
In fact, water plays a key role in the degradation of BP as we learned from the degradation mechanism (section 2.3). Hence, coating the BP flake with a barrier against water diffusion, such
as a capping layer made of 300nm of parylene C, seems effective in preventing degradation.52 Similarly, Tayari et al. deposited 300 nm of methylmethacrylate (MMA) and 200 nm of polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) on BP FETs to form a waterimpermeable superstrate-suppressing oxidation.83 Apparently, the thick polymer cover layers do not match up the pursuit of ultrathin devices. Alternatively, self-assembled organic monolayers by vacuum physical vapor deposition benefit from well-controllable thickness (down to few nm), sustainable stability, oxidation resistance, and elimination of electronic devices degradation.84 Our group proposed self-assembly of perylene-3,4,9,10-tetracarboxylic dianhydride (PTCDA) monolayers, which have a strong self-assembly capacity and are able to self-assemble into stable and well-ordered MLs on various substrates, on BP to achieve the fine encapsulation.85 Our multi-scale simulations demonstrate PTCDA molecules do not break the original electronic properties of BP and are able to self-assemble into a stable and close-packed herringbone hydrogen-bonded network due to hydrogen bonds (Fig. 5d). Meanwhile, PTCDA monolayers can well isolate BP from the ambient O2 and H2O when its thickness amounts to about 2 nm (Fig. 5e). The model system was further validated by Wang et al. that no oxidized phosphorus peak is observed for BP with 3.2 nm PTCDA protection layer upon 3 hours air exposure, while pristine BP suffers fast oxidation according to XPS experiments.86 Similarly, Artel et al. passivated BP with selfassembled monolayers of octadecyltrichlorosilane (OTS), thus gaining important advantages in terms of stability, oxidation resistance, and elimination of electronic devices degradation.84
It is important to note that BP nanoparticles are stable in aqueous dispersions for several weeks like deaerated water (section 2.1.1), thus the exfoliation of BP and fabrication of BP devices can be conducted in mixed solutions, in which the pristine BP presents better stability compared with air environment. The acquired few-layers BP by liquid phase exfoliation made use of high boiling organic solvents, such as NMP, DMF, DMSO, and CHP, impart greater stability in the air compared with micromechanically exfoliated BP, presumably due to surface adsorption of the residual solvent.39-42 For example, the stability under ambient conditions increases from approximately 1 h for mechanically cleaved BP to about 200 h for CHP exfoliated few layer BP.40 In a solution environment, Abellán et al. functionalized bulk BP with 7,7,8,8-tetracyano-pquinodi-methane (TCNQ) and perylene bisimide (PDI) and the process produced stable hybrids on the surface of the BP flakes and PDI improved the robustness of the BP flakes against oxygen as well.87 Gusmão et al. improved chemical stabilization of BP by noncovalent modification with antraquinone (AQ), limiting BP degradation in atmospheric conditions and additional redox functionality that can provide additional charge storage capacity.88
The protection mechanism of organic coating is not simply as isolation of water and oxygen, as the different organic molecules, TCNQ and PDI for example, have significantly different protection capability. PDI at BP surface shows faster trapping photogenerated electron capability than TCNQ, which effectively suppresses the formation of O2- and thereby protects BP from oxidation. Meanwhile, PDI can hold photogenerated electrons for a very long time, which would improve the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs in BP and thereby increases the internal quantum efficiency of BP.
Encapsulation with organic layers has many merits including low cost, large-scale preparation and nondestructivity towards properties of BP.90, 91 However, in the long-term exposure, the weak intermolecular interaction is not stable enough to prevent active species of O2 and H2O, even in cases like hydrogen bonding, for example, supramolecular networks of trimesic acid and melamine cyanurate, improves the connection.92 As a consequence, oxygen and water may enter through the interfaces causing eventual breakdown of the ultrathin 2D materials. Tightly packed shells with more robust networks in close proximity to the ultrathin 2D material surfaces, therein, are highly desirable for improving the stability. Our group proposed to link the weakly bonded organics to strong covalently bonding by adding transitional metals, i.e. a solution processed on-surface synthesis of metalorganic frameworks for fine encapsulation of air unstable ultrathin 2D materials. A reported nonporous 2D thin film of copper coordination polymer,93 Cu-BHT (BHT=benzenehexathiol), was investigated in terms of formation process and the protection effect.94 Electronic structure calculations have shown that the 2D polymer encapsulation of BP does not worsen the desirable electronic properties compared to pristine monolayers. This offers the prospect of stable passivated flakes, allowing BP devices to function in ambient conditions. Our dynamic simulations demonstrate the preparation of the 2D polymer network on the surface of BP can be achieved in a solution environment, which could avoid the oxidation of pristine materials in the first place. Finally, we have proved that the diffusion of oxygen and water can be suppressed by covering the flakes with a monolayer of 2D polymer, and their ultrathin character allows minimum interference with the properties of the underlying materials (Fig. 5f).

sections.heading: 2.2.2 Limiting or sequestration of reactive oxygen species
2.2.2.1 Covalent modification and coordination
sections.text:
The above-mentioned encapsulation methods rely on the noncovalent interaction between the capping layer and BP
substrate, while covalent methods, determined to be efficient in manipulating the chemical and electronic properties of nanomaterials, have also been reported. Such chemical modification schemes generally consist of two approaches, covalent modification and coordination with transitional metals. Ryder et al. demonstrated that the exfoliated BP nanosheets could be stabilized with p-methoxybenzene diazonium and p-nitrobenzene diazonium salts via formation of phosphorus–carbon covalent bonds (Fig. 6a).95 The functionalized BP nanosheets show no obvious degradation even after 3 weeks and the benzene ring enhances the electron mobility and switching ratio of the BP FET. Covalent modifications occupy surface phosphorous atoms, thereby avoid the contact between the air mixture and BP surface. Nevertheless, the molecules modification can hardly reach to a 100% seamless coverage, and there are naked phosphorous atoms which can still be reactive to air. Further theoretical calculations by our group revealed that the passivation effect also relates to the production of reactive oxygen species, O2-.96 Certain molecule modification causes a potential jump and shifts the CBM of BP below the redox potential of O2/O2- (Fig. 6b), and thereby it is hard to produce O2- and improves the ambient stability of BP. In addition, we proposed to use polymers bonded to BP surface, aiming at a balance between functionality and carrier mobility. Tang et al. identified P-F bonds formed on the BP surface by Fourier transformed infrared (FTIR) spectra, and the fluorinated phosphorene was found to exhibit enhanced air stability thanks to the antioxidation and antihydration effects of the introduced fluorine adatoms, and demonstrated excellent photothermal stability during a week of air exposure.97 Ni et al. reached to a long stability up to one year by poly (vinyl alcohol) (PVA) oxidized BP nanosheets, and XPS analysis indicates approximately complete coverage of oxygen on PVA-coated BP nanosheets achieved, thus BP composites cannot be further transformed into phosphoric acid by water-induced etching.98

sections.heading: 2.2.2.2 Doping and coordination
sections.text:
Elemental doping is another conventional technique semiconductor processing for modulation of electronic properties. Our combined experimental and theoretical study indicated that Te-doped BP devices exhibit an exceptional ability to resist ambient degradation with a retained mobility of >200 cm2V-1s-1 and ON/OFF current ratio of ≈500, after 21 days of ambient exposure (Fig. 6c).99 The passivation mechanism, again, is attributed to the shift of the CBM. Specifically, the band edges of undoped BP are above the redox potential of O2-O2- , while the Te-doping shifts the CBM of BP significantly close to or even below the redox potential of O2-O2-. Therefore, the possibility of generation of light-induced O2 is significantly reduced, and the oxidation process of BP is abated (Fig. 6d).
Yu’s group synthesized a titanium benzenesulfonate ligand (TiL4), which can coordinate with the BP lone-pair electrons.100 In contrast to serious degradation observed from the bare BP nanosheets, the TiL4-BP nanosheets exhibit excellent stability during long-term dispersion in water as well as exposure to air,

sections.heading: 2.2.2.4 Ionic liquids
sections.text: Ionic liquids, a kind of molten salts like 1-butyl-3methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate [BMIM] [BF4], 1- hydroxyethyl-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethansulfonate ([HOEMIM]-[TfO] and 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate, have been used for effective solvents for liquid exfoliation to yield stable and high-concentration suspensions of nanoflakes of BP.105-107 Similar as organic coating effect (section 3.1.3), it appears that BP layers covering the flakes with ionic liquid minimize oxidation by forming a stable protective solvation shell. For example, Abellán et al. showed the passivation BP by BMIM-BF4 exhibits an outstanding stability for months under environmental conditions.106 In addition to the isolation of oxygen and water, Walia et al. inferred that [BMIM][BF4] provides a unique ability to protect BP via sequestration of the damaging reactive oxygen species, namely, singlet oxygen species, as well as hydroxyl and superoxide radicals (Fig. 6g).108 The ESEM studies validated the generation of reactive oxygen species by exposure of BP to light, and artificial compounds such as imidazoles have been found to sequester these damaging species, allowing BP to remain stable for over 13 weeks, while retaining its key electronic characteristics.

sections.heading: 2.2.3 Passivation effect on BP properties
sections.text:
One of the key prerequisites for an effective protection strategy is to see if any significant alterations occur to the geometric and electronic-structures of BP when it is encapsulated by protection layers. As common applied ALD process, it is revealed that H2O molecules, one of the precursors in ALD Al2O3 process, can serve as a surface oxidant for phosphorene if phosphorus oxide is formed on the surface prior to deposition.73 Therefore, the starting surface plays a critical role in ALD nucleation and the controlled functionalization methods will need to be developed. In addition, moisture is present again at the BP surface layer after the ALD process and causes charge trap impurities in BP devices.109 Alternatively, the high quality BN–BP–BN heterostructure well preserves the pristine BP properties, and shows excellent stability in the atmospheric environment with a high mobility ~1,350 cm2V-1s-1 and a large on–off ratio exceeding 105.75 Linear-scaling density functional theory simulations proves that hBN-encapsulation preserves the main electronic properties of the BP monolayer, while hBN spacers can be used to counteract the band gap reduction in stacked BP.110 The well preserved BP property by h-BN encapsulation can be attributed to the weak interaction between the two 2D materials. In this respect, other protection strategies, such as organic coating, surface oxidation, and interface engineering, is also expected to have a slight effect on the electronic properties of pristine BP. sections.heading: 3. Transitional metal dichalcogenides
sections.text:
TMDCs exist in several structural phases resulting from different coordination spheres of the transition metal atoms, and three main polymorphs of TMDCs are 1T, 2H and 3R, corresponding to the trigonal, hexagonal and rhombohedral phases, respectively (Fig. 8a). The intralayer M–X bonds are predominantly covalent in nature, whereas the sandwich layers are coupled by weak van der Waals forces thus allowing the crystal to readily cleave along the layer surface. Subsequently, a single and few-layer thickness of TMDCs can be prepared by
various ways, such as mechanical exfoliation, CVD, liquid exfoliation and chemical synthesis.5, 22, 111 It is realized that Group IV-VIIB TMDCs are predominantly layered, while some of Group VIIIB TMDCs are commonly found in non-layered structures. The lone-pair electrons of the chalcogenide atoms terminate the surfaces of the layers, and the absence of dangling bonds in the perfect crystalline structure renders those layers stable against reactions with environmental species. Therein, TMDCs have been considered as air-stable materials under ambient conditions. Nevertheless, the electronic properties of 2D MX2 are known to be highly sensitive to instinct effects such as edges, grain boundaries, and surface vacancies. These sites, on one hand, offers opportunities for chemical modifications, sensing applications, and catalytic reactions.5, 112 On the other hand, the oxidation process arises from the reaction between active species in the air and exposed M atoms by the defects.113, 114

Energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy results suggest that the changes were oxidized MoS2 sites which had a higher concentration of Mo atoms due to evaporation of sulphur dioxide and formation of MoO3, which is hygroscopic. DFT calculations have confirmed molecular oxygen can easily dissociate into individual atoms at edge sites, whereas the pristine MoS2 surface presents good stability. A large kinetic barrier of 1.6 eV for O2 dissociation and chemisorption on MoS2 surface and the calculated dissociation barrier at edge sites is as low as 0.31 eV. Consequently, the edges and grain boundaries of MoS2 are susceptible to oxidation.118, 119 Instead of Mo induced adsorption, it is proposed that O2 connects to edge sulphur atoms in the beginning and forms SO2. The detachment of the SO2 group leaves a sulphur vacancy at the edge, into which oxygen atoms can bind. Thus, the S-terminated MoS2 edge turns into a onedimensional chain-like structure resembling that of bulk MoO3, which is a possible starting point for further morphological changes in MoS2. In addition to active edge sites, sulphur vacancies at the surface of MoS2 are expected to reduce the oxidation kinetic barrier to 0.8 eV and this is in agreement with the experimental evidence that defect sites on the MoS2 surface exhibit high reactivity and are readily filled by oxygen atoms.120 Except for air exposure, it was also found by AFM that MoS2 is thermodynamically unstable in water, and needle-like protrusions in the range of 20−50 nm can be formed on the surface after the sample had been immersed in water for 1 h.121 XPS and atomic absorption spectroscopy (AAS) analyses showed that this behavior might arise from the oxidation of MoS2 into Mo(VI), which in the form of either MoO3·H2O crystals or molybdate ions in aqueous solution, and SO42- that present in the solution.
It appears that the oxidation of WS2 is more severe than that of MoS2.113 The PL intensity of the 1-year-aged WS2 sample is ∼6 times lower as compared to the fresh WS2, while the PL intensity of the 1-year-aged MoS2 sample was measured to be ∼2.3 times lower as compared to the fresh MoS2. Kang et al. showed oxidized grain boundaries of an as-grown polycrystalline WS2 monolayer on a SiO2 substrate become clearly visible in the optical image after a few weeks.122 In contrast to edge and grain boundary initiated oxidation (arbitrary shapes), the interior oxidation of single-crystalline WS2 monolayers on a SiO2 substrate, which presents triangular or hexagonal (composed of triangular sections) in shape, is observed as well. Interestingly, the substrate effect is magnified, as the WS2 on graphene suspended on a TEM grid did not show any sign of oxidation for over a ten month period,
and the prolonged stability is attributed to a lack of defects and screening effect of surface electric field caused by the substrate.
Similar to sulphides, the edges of selenides react with ambient molecules and form partially oxidized edges.123, 124 STM image shows that the edges of the monolayer WSe2, which exposed in the air for 9 weeks, are decorated by air-induced protrusions with a height of 0.83 ± 0.03 nm. The STS spectra indicates the VBM to Fermi level energy reduces by 0.61 ± 0.04 V from terrace to edge, while the CBM to Fermi level energy increases by 0.47 ± 0.04 V from 0 V. Therefore, the band gap of the air-exposed edge is larger by 1.08 ± 0.08 eV than band gap of air-exposed terrace, and reaches to 3.15 ± 0.03 eV, which is very close to the theoretically calculated band gap of oxide product WO3. However, the oxidation with air exposure is observed only at step edges after exposure of WSe2 in air for 9 weeks, while it is not detected on the internal terraces, thus the oxidation of step edges in WSe2 appears to be a self-terminating process.
Unlike sulphides and selenides, tellurides, MoTe2 and WTe2, surfer from surface oxidation and are the most active species among Group VIBs TMDCs.120, 125-128 It is demonstrated that Te atoms desorb easily from both the basal plane and the edge plane even at low temperatures.125 The air exposure of MoTe2 induces significant material growth from 0.6 nm of pristine MoTe2 to 1.02 ± 0.06nm, while the inside structure of MoTe2 is maintained.129 PS shows that the Te peak shifts by 3.42 eV from 572.71 eV for MoTe2 to 576.13 eV, corresponds to the peak position of TeO2. Meanwhile, a Mo-3d peak at 227.70 eV for MoTe2 shifts to 232.36eV, which is consistent with the peak position of MoO3. The easy oxidation, no doubt, changes the electronic properties of MoTe2 and has a negative effect on the performance of MoTe2 based FETs, including drain voltage and carrier mobility. From the Raman spectrum, it’s observed that single-layer WTe2 degrades fairly fast in ambient conditions, and it shows some signs of degradation during the exfoliation process that only takes 4–5 minutes.126 XPS spectra of the degraded WTe2 shows clear oxidation signatures of both Te and W atoms on the surface of the degraded WTe2, including an appearance of Te-O peaks at the binding energy of 576.1 and 587.1 eV near Te-3d band and W-O peaks at the binding energy of 247.4 and 260.6 eV near W-4d band. These XPS observations indicate that the main mechanism of degradation of WTe2 in ambient conditions is oxidation of both W and Te atoms, and TeO2 and WOx (2 < x < 3) are the main oxidation products. Like BP, the stability of WTe2 is layer dependent, and the Raman peaks in 2L and 3L WTe2 still remain clearly detectable after 15 days of exposure to ambient conditions, showing much higher environmental stability compared with that of 1L WTe2. It is assumed that the generated oxidation products such as WOx and TeO2 passivate the WTe2 surface and prevents oxygen from further diffusing into the inside of lattice and protecting inner layer of WTe2.

The calculated d band center is located at −2.67 and −2.35 eV for MoS2 and MoSe2, and −2.92 and −2.58 eV for WS2 and WSe2, respectively. As a deeper d-band center indicates a stronger the M-X bond, thus the transitional sulphides bonding are stronger than selenides. In addition, with the same chalcogen atom (X), O2 gained more electrons from WX2 than MoX2 and interacted more strongly with WX2 because W has a greater reducibility than Mo.

sections.heading: 3.2 Semiconducting Group IVB dicholoniges
sections.text:
Group IVB TMDCs (M = Ti, Zr, Hf) adopt 1T phase, which is more stable than 2H phase under normal conditions, and one transition metal atom coordinates with six neighbouring chalcogen atoms form into an octahedral configuration. The properties of Group IVB TMDCs can be either semiconductors or semimetals, where Zirconium and hafnium disulphides and diselenides (including ZrS2, ZrSe2, HfS2, and HfSe2) are all semiconductors with indirect bandgaps; and TiSe2 and tellurides (TiTe2, ZrTe2, and HfTe2) show semimetal behaviours with a small overlap between the top of the p-orbital chalcogen valence band and the bottom of the d-orbital transition metal conduction band.8 However, the electronic character of TiS2 is hard to specify, since there is a wide range of existing reported values for the bandgap of TiS2 and no final conclusion have been made whether it belongs to metals, semimetals, or semiconductors. One possible explanation for this range of values is that the samples of TiS2 being measured had already undergone some small degree of oxidation. From experimental side, the edges of liquid phase exfoliated TiS2 flakes show an amorphous layer approximately 2 nm thick, and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) reveals that this consists of Ti and O while the center part is composed of pure Ti and S.132 In addition, the presence of carbon along the edges and on the top of the flakes is also detected. From theoretical calculations, thermodynamic analysis has revealed that the oxidation either takes place at the flake edges with 50% terminated in sulphur or initiated by the presence of a surface vacancy (Fig. 9a). The overall rate-limiting stage of the oxidation reaction at edge site and the transition state is 1.1 eV above the energy of the initial configuration. Long et al. confirmed that the oxidation of TiS2 starts at the edges and the oxidation region grew ~80nm into the flake after the sample is stored in H2O for 21 days.133 Furthermore, an additional oxidation process explored was the reaction with oxygen gas, and the loss of crystallinity at the edge is demonstrated by Fast Fourier Transforms (FFT). Therefore, the oxide can form along boundary defects by oxygen exposure, but the growth into the bulk of the flake is limited. The results suggest moisture to be the critical element to remove from their environment in order to ensure long-term stability, and it is proposed that the induced oxidation mechanism could be envisaged as having two stages. Firstly, the direct contact between sulphur in the outermost surface regions and oxygen leads to hydrogen sulphide, which is noticeable from the smell. Secondly, titanium in non-surface layers seems to diffuse out to react with oxygen, like the nanoscale Kirkendall effect, whereby atoms diffuse via vacancy exchange, with preferential diffusion of cations outwards over anions inwards. The increase in thickness is attributed to the formation a less dense amorphous structure. The oxide layers on the surface, then, prevents both the removal of sulphur and inward-diffusion of oxygen, leading to the formation of the observed depletion region.
As the radius grows from Ti to Hf, the mobility of MX2 increases, but the air stability drops dramatically.134 Severe structural degradation of HfS2 thin films after exposure to air even for a few hours was observed through AFM and Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 9b).114 The HfS2 surface revealed the presence of small bubbles after 4 h of oxidation, while the thickness increased simultaneously, which was attributed to the expanded interlayer distance due to oxidation. The humidity, similar with oxidation of other 2D materials, accelerates the oxidation process severely, but the possibility of oxygen contribution cannot be excluded. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analysis for oxidized HfS2 revealed that S atoms, in fact, are replaced by oxygen atoms during oxidation, and the Hf atomic percentage remained unchanged. Also, the thickness expansion by about 250% at a prolonged exposure time of >120 h is observed, and it is attributed to intercalated oxygen atoms between layers. HfSe2, an n-type semiconductor with a smaller band gap than HfS2, shows significant top-down degradation into an amorphous oxide in an ambient condition observed by cross-sectional TEM, and the oxidation appears to be neither self-limiting in time nor restricted by layer boundaries.135 Elemental mapping confirms replacement of Se by O in the top-oxide versus the layered bulk. Comparing with HfS2, the RMS roughness of HfSe2 is higher during the period studied. The degradation of HfSe2 is visible 1day after exfoliation, while signs of degradation are only visible 9 days after exfoliation for HfS2.130 The surface of HfSe2 is characterized by several protrusions randomly located across the surface. SEM analysis suggests that the blisters (small protrusions) have a higher density at the step-edges, which may be optimal nucleation sites for the growth of the features. EDX compositional analysis notice that the blister is primarily composed of Se, with only trace amounts of Hf. The XPS study data for HfSe2 as a function of ambient exposure clearly shows the progressive loss of Se from within the XPS sampling depth (5–7nm) over the 48h monitoring period, with the Se:Hf ratio reducing from the initial 2:1 to 1.4:1. The FWHM of the 48h exposed sample is 2.9 eV at 530.9 eV binding energy, which
corresponds to HfO2 peak, indicating the formation of Hf oxide while the Se oxides are not detected. Mleczko et al. suggested that ambient oxidation is not self-limiting for the layered selenides, ostensibly aided by oxygen diffusion through atomicscale imperfections, such as Se vacancies.136
The air stability of ZrX2 is also a matter of concern, and the oxidation effects are expected to be much more dramatic in thinner flakes. Zhang et al. performed Raman spectra to identify the ZrS2 flake, but no peaks were observed for the ZrS2 monolayer and bilayers, possibly because of the weak signal and easy oxidation of the ZrS2 monolayer and bilayer under laser irradiation in atmosphere.137 Similarly, Galbiati et al. show that no Raman signal could be observed on the thin flakes after sample exposition to the air for some days.138 Even using a low laser power density (170 µW/µm2), flakes were revealed to be easily degraded during the measurement if the exposition time was not sufficiently short. AFM tapping image of a ZrS2 flake after exposure to the laser for some minutes clears shows a hole of about 1.9 nm produced by the laser over the flake surface. The oxidation effect of ZrSe2 was observed on the order of seconds, which is more dramatic than ZrS2 on the order of minutes. Cross-sectional TEM image of a smaller (<50 nm thick, <10 mm in lateral size) ZrSe2 flake following 3 days of ambient exposure, demonstrating both top-down and bottom-up oxidation into amorphous ZrOx, which partially consumes individual layers.136 EDX mapping of elemental lines indicates a clear displacement of Se by O in structurally amorphous regions, relative to the layered bulk, whereas constant metal concentrations throughout suggest the formation of substoichiometric ZrOx.

sections.heading: 3.3 Metallic Group IV-VB dicholoniges
sections.text:
Metallic TMDCs such as 1T-TiSe2, 2H-NbSe2, 1T-TaS2, and 1TTaSe2 are found to exhibit generic instabilities towards the symmetry-lowering charge density wave (CDW) state and superconductivity and, therefore, are ideal platforms to investigate in a controlled manner the interplay between these phases.25, 139, 140 These ultrathin 2D TMDCs films provided important insights into the origins of superconductivity and CDW in TMDCs which have been a longstanding question in condensed matter physics. Besides, these 2D TMDCs also show potential applications in advanced low-power electronics, especially for 2D TiSe2 which allows for tuning the phase transitions over a broad range of temperatures by applying gate voltage. However, metallic TMDCs show even higher oxidation tendency than BP under ambient conditions, thus the oxidation, in turn, disturb the instinct properties of the materials. Sun et al. found that thinner TiSe2 flakes did not show CDW transition (for a thickness of ca. 5–8 nm) or were even insulating (<5 nm), owing to the unavoidable oxidation during the device fabrication process (Fig. 9c).25 The morphology change induced by oxidation is quite obvious, and the height of a TiSe2 flake measured with AFM increased from about 11 nm to about 14 nm in 5 days and finally to about 18 nm after 10 days exposure. Auger electron spectroscopy (AES) further characterized that O and Ti elements were homogeneously distributed in the heavily oxidized TiSe2 flakes, indicating that the TiSe2 flakes were oxidized into TiO2. XPS shows the most prominent peak is located at about 530–531 eV, which is related to the bridging oxygen, indicating the presence of the intermediate structure of Se-O-Ti. Therefore, in a complete picture of oxidation mechanism, TiSe2 thin flakes are firstly oxidized to form an intermediate of TiOxSe2-x at the edges and defects on the topmost layer, then the metastable Se-O-Ti bonds are gradually broken and lead to the oxidation product of Se and TiO2. Selenium was trapped in the van der Waals gaps and accumulates into larger particles to expand the interlayer spacing, thus facilitate the diffusion of O2 and finally lead to the complete oxidation of multilayered flakes from both edges to basal plane and top to bottom in a layer-by-layer manner. The oxidation behaviour of other metallic TMDCs such as TaSe2 and NbSe2 is similar to that of TiSe2, except that these materials are more stable than TiSe2. Wang et al. observed the local atomic structure of the grain boundaries in the air-sensitive NbSe2 monolayer grown on SiO2/Si by the protection of the graphene sandwich structure, and these grain boundaries can be easily oxidized in ambient conditions.139
Tellurides including TiTe2, ZrTe2, and HfTe2 show semimetal behaviours, and this series materials are studied considerably less. Thin layers of tellurides have been reported in very recent years, and single-layer limit emerges novel properties, which are different from those of the bulk counterpart.141, 142 For example, the emergence of a (2×2) charge density wave order in single-layer TiTe2 with a transition temperature of 92±3K is observed, while no charge density wave transitions were observed in two-layer and multi-layer TiTe2, despite the quasi-two-dimensional nature of the material in the bulk. The oxidation of taknides is not studied yet, but metallic 2D crystals are more likely to be unstable than insulating and semiconducting ones, owing to the generally higher reactivity of metals.24 Therefore, all the samples were either capped with protection layers, such as Al, Te, or conduct in an inert atmosphere during experiments.

sections.heading: 3.4 Protection strategies
sections.text:
To date, the protection schemes for passivation of TMDCs from air exposure are in a simple form of encapsulation, and the encapsulation layers include polymer, atomic layer deposition (ALD)-grown Al2O3, and other air inert 2D materials of graphene and h-BN.25, 122, 125, 127, 143 In particular, h-BN encapsulation, cannot only avoid or mitigate degradation, but also enhance device surface/interface quality and carrier mobility.126, 144 However, the preparation processes require precision instruments, sophisticated technology, and inert atmosphere. Alternatively, polymer coating after exfoliation and atomic layer
deposition (ALD)-grown Al2O3 coating benefit from facile preparation, and the capping layers have been proven to be an effective approach to protecting WS2, MoTe2, and WTe2 crystals and maintaining the intrinsic properties of 2D materials.143, 145 Nevertheless, long-term air stability of such encapsulation still needs further experimental validations.

sections.heading: 4. Metal choloniges
sections.text:
Besides TMDCs, Group IIIA and IVA choloniges (such as InSe, GaSe, and SnSe2) also contribute to the family of layered semiconductors. They have a similar configuration as MoS2, in which Metal layer is sandwiched between non-metal layers to form a stable “three-layer” structure. In the case of MSe (M=In, Ga), metal layers consist of two effectively covalently bonded metals. Likewise, various synthesis methods have been developed to prepare high quality of Group IIIA-IVA materials, such as molecular beam epitaxy (MBE),146, 147 CVD,148, 149 and mechanical exfoliation.150, 151 It is also highlight the potential applications related III−VI 2D materials in optoelectronics,
energy application, piezoelectricity and photodetector.149, 152-154 In terms of electrical transport device, the two-terminal room temperature field effect mobility of the InSe FET can be improved to be ~103 cm2 V−1 s−1 at room temperatures which is well above that of the TMDCs.151, 155 However, the set of

Compared to slow degradation of InSe, few-layered GaSe exhibit higher surface chemical reactivity for various configurations of chemical species in air and show a fast drop in PL intensity upon a few days of exposure.151 By employing ab initio electronic structure calculations and molecular dynamics simulations, we found two oxidation process involved in the case of GaSe surface, light-induced oxidation, and SeVs-induced oxidation. The highly active O2- is generated by light-induced electron transfer and reacts with the surface of GaSe, resulting in the insertion of oxygen atoms into the in-plane of GaSe (Fig. 10b). In addition, under the polarization effect of water, it facilitates the electron transfer from GaSe to oxygen, easily forming O2-. Therefore, the oxidation process of GaSe is accelerated in humid condition comparing with a dry environment.157, 160

sections.heading: 5. Application in Field Effect Transistors
sections.text:
Two-dimensional materials, which represent the ultimate limit of miniaturization in the vertical dimension, provide the option of ultimate thin transistors and the opportunity for new device concepts, as they would allow a very high degree of electrostatic control. Unlike graphene, many 2D TMDCs and BP are semiconductor in nature and possess huge potential to be made into ultra-small and flexible transistors that are more efficient than state-of-the-art silicon based transistors. The first
and a representative example of 2D vdW based FET would be MoS2.161, 162 In 2011, Kis group implemented a 6.5 Å thick MoS2 into a transistor device as semiconducting channel (Fig. 11a).7 It is deposited on SiO2 and covered by a 30 nm thick layer of HfO2, which serves as the top-gate dielectric. The device shows a current on/off ratio exceeding 108 at room temperature offstate currents smaller than 100 fA (25 fA/μm). In the following studies, the group demonstrated the mobility of MoS2 is phonon-limited and can be fitted to the power law μ ∝ 𝑇𝑇−𝛾𝛾 , with γ in the range of 0.55−0.78, which is much smaller than the theoretical prediction for a single-layer (γ ≈ 1.52) or bulk crystals (γ ≈ 2.6).161, 163 The low mobility have been attributed to many reasons such as scattering of carriers by substrate roughness, charged impurities, adsorbates on the surface, electron-phonon coupling and so on.164, 165 In particular, environmental factors are typically crucial ones. Hone group developed a van der Waals heterostructure device platform where MoS2 layers are fully encapsulated within hexagonal boron nitride and electrically contacted in a multi-terminal geometry using gatetunable graphene electrodes.144, 166 The hBN-encapsulation provides excellent protection from extrinsic sources and show dramatic improvements in performance, including a record high Hall mobility reaching 34,000 cm2 V−1 s−1 for six-layer MoS2 at low temperature, high two-terminal carrier mobility (33-151 cm2 V−1 s−1) and low subthreshold swing (80mV/dec) at room temperature. The results support the statement that the lowtemperature performance of MoS2-based FET was limited by extrinsic interfacial impurities rather than bulk defects.

The BN overlayer allowed passivated HfS2-FETs to maintain a high on/off ratio of ∼105 for more than a week under ambient conditions. However, The BN passivation layer could not completely prevent the HfS2 layer from reacting with oxygen species after a week. The effective protection schemes for TMDCs are still highly required.
As one of the promising 2D semiconductors, BP serves as a 2D crystal that bridges optoelectronic properties between zerobandgap high-mobility graphene and large-bandgap lowmobility TMDCs. In this regard, field-effect transistors based on few-layer black phosphorus has emerged since 2014, and offered ambipolar transport with hole and electron mobilities higher than the established thin- film materials based on metal oxides, organic semiconductors and amorphous Si.14, 27, 167 Chen et al. reported the fabrication of stable sandwiched heterostructures by encapsulating atomically thin black phosphorus between hexagonal boron nitride layers to realize ultra-clean interfaces that allow a high field-effect mobility of ~1,350cm cm2 V−1 s−1 at room temperature and on–off ratios exceeding 105.75 To achieve both high mobility and stability of BP FETs under atmospheric conditions, the BN–BP–BN configuration and high-temperature annealing are the two key factors, where the annealing process can significantly reduce the charge trap density in BP as no hysteresis effect is observed at room temperature. Zhu et al report the first flexible black phosphorus (BP) field-effect transistors (FETs) supported on flexible polyimide (Fig. 11b).168 The device has a patterned-gate architecture with 30 nm-thick ALD Al2O3 dielectrics on top, which has simultaneously been used as device encapsulation layer. The experimental BP transistors showed afforded maximum carrier mobility of about 310 cm2 V−1 s−1 with fieldeffect current modulation exceeding 3 orders of magnitude and robust performance under mechanical bending up to ∼2% tensile strain and 5000 bending cycles.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions and Perspectives
sections.text:
Over the past decade, 2D materials that beyond graphene have achieved great progress as the next generation electronic materials. Nevertheless, limited mainly by oxidation processes, the experimental performance of ultrathin 2D materials is far from the practical applications. Consequently, there is great potential worth exploring in the understanding of the oxidation and degradation mechanisms and finding appropriate passivation schemes, otherwise, all the efforts for property investigations will be in vain.
The review firstly highlights the degradation of BP in ambient conditions, from the oxidation process on the surface to a fully collapse and disappearance of the top layers. The whole scheme can be divided into three steps, the generation of reactive oxygen species, the oxidation process and eventual breakdown under the action of water. The synergic effect of light, water and oxygen accounts for the fast oxidation phenomenon of BP, and the light-induced oxidation and water catalyzed oxidation mechanisms, in particular, are discussed. The passivation mechanism of commonly applied protection strategies is either attributed to the direct isolation of BP from air or sequestration /limitation the generation of reactive oxygen species, leading to prolonged stability of few-layer BP up to days or months, depending on the fabrication methods.
The instability becomes a label for few-layer BP now, while other authors have taken advantage of this stability issue and proposed using BP in humidity sensors.169, 170 It appears that significant progress has been made both experimentally and theoretically to understand the exact mechanism of BP surface oxidation. The fast surface oxidation mechanisms of BP induced by light and water can be extended to other environmental unstable 2D materials, such as GaSe, which suffers from fast oxidation within a few days.160 However, it should be clear that whether the oxidation of 2D materials initiates from the surface or not. The pristine surfaces of 2D materials can be quite inert and the oxidation may be attributed to defect sites such as point defects, edges and grain boundaries.159 Therefore, a comprehensive description of BP degradation should also involve the participation of defect sites, which could play a substantial role in the degradation process and require further study.171 Besides, the light effect on BP is crucial while the explicit description of complicated photo-excitation processes demands more sophisticated techniques. For instance, theoretical methods need to advance to a level of timedependent DFT or non-adiabatic molecular dynamics, more than simply ground state based DFT.
MoS2 appears to be the most stable layered materials in the family of chalcogenides, other MX or MX2, however, suffers from oxidation at different levels depending on several factors, including metals, chalcogens, and coordination geometries. Several general trends can be concluded from available results. For instance, metallic ones are more reactive comparing with semiconductors; defect sites like edges, grain boundaries and surface vacancies initiate the oxidation process; the oxidation rates are increasing as the chalcogen changing from S to Se to Te. Nevertheless, to understand the oxidation process better more studies under controlled atmospheres are required. We list several unclear points and challenges regarding the oxidation and encapsulation of BP, TMDCs and MCs here for the promotion of further studies.
Firstly, the inducing factors of oxidation and degradation of TMDCs and MCs should be identified, and the reaction mechanisms should be revealed. Oxygen is the most abundant oxidant in the air, and the O atoms present stronger electronegativity comparing with chalcogen, indicating a thermodynamically favorable process of the replacement of chalcogen atoms by O. However, there are also pieces of evidence for surface oxidation of TMDCs and MCs that similar to BP, especially tellurides, which requires further studies. Except for oxygen, it is widely observed that humanity plays an important role in the oxidation and degradation process. Nevertheless, it is not clear whether H2O directly react with the materials or the H2O react as a catalyst for oxidation by O2, and the synergistic effect between water and oxygen should be clarified. In addition, light can be another essential factor that triggers the oxidation due to electron excitation and charge transfer process. Secondly, the oxidation products need to be characterized, and the products, in turn, can reflect the reaction mechanisms. The oxidation of TMDCs and MCs all lead to MxOy, while other products are depending on the chalcogen. The sulphides are reported to generate H2S in a typical smell; selenides often lead to elemental Se following with large sample growth; tellurides produce TeO2. It is worth noticing that the oxidation from top layer or edges in several cases, like WTe2,126 can be a self-limiting process, and the formed MxOy can serve as protection layers from further oxidation while other systems are continuous react with oxygen and water till complete oxidation. Therefore, understanding the self-limiting mechanism has great potential for self-protection in the longterm exposure. Thirdly, finding effective, stable and low-cost ways to protect the 2D surfaces from degradation is still highly challenging. Encapsulation by Al2O3 seems to present long-term stability, and the method has advantages in the large-scale preparation. However, such encapsulations also trap defects and impurities, which have negative effects on carrier mobility. To avoid oxidation or other chemical reactions during the ALD process, pre-treatment of the sample layers such as surface oxidation and organic coating should be performed. Hydrophobic materials can also be deposited on the surface to build another solid barrier for penetration of oxygen and water. Encapsulation of h-BN/GR is one common strategy that applied to obtain high interface quality, but the protection efficiency is still very limited, not to mention the strict preparation conditions and complicated technologies. On the other hand, surface modification of BP in aqueous solutions provides another versatile and effective way of BP functionalization and passivation, and future studies need to identify ideal potential surface protectants. These methods can be also extended to other 2D materials, which requires further tests. The modifications that verify fulfil the following two conditions can be considered: (i) Long-term stability; the surface modification both covalently or non-covalently should either isolate active species well by tight framework or has the ability of limitation or sequestration of reactive oxygen species effectively. (ii) Well preserved electronic properties; the surface modification should not break the original electronic properties of 2D materials. Finally, a comprehensive understanding of the degradation mechanisms, and promising protection approaches that aiming at the degradation mechanisms, will facilitate the applications of 2D materials in various fields in the near future.
